title-group.article-title: Parametric eigenstructure assignment using state-derivative feedback for linear systems

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Helwan University, Helwan, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Taha Helmy S Abdelaziz, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Helwan University, 1 Sherif Street, 11792 Helwan, Egypt Email: tahahelmy@helwan.edu.eg

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper addresses a complete parametric approach for solving the eigenstructure assignment problem using state-derivative feedback for multivariable linear systems. In the present work, both linear control systems with nonsingular and singular open-loop state matrices are treated and the corresponding parametric expressions to the feedback gains are derived. The parametric expressions for gains describe the available degrees-of-freedom offered by the state-derivative feedback in selecting the associated eigenvectors from an admissible class. These freedoms are utilized to improve robustness of the closed-loop system. Accordingly, the sensitivity of the assigned eigenvalues to perturbations in the system and gain matrices is minimized. Finally, a vibration absorber system is introduced to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed solution.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Eigenstructure assignment (ESA) is one of the basic techniques for designing linear control systems. The ESA problem is the problem of assigning both a given set of eigenvalues and the corresponding eigenvectors. Assigning eigenvalues allows one to alter the stability characteristics of the system, while assigning eigenvectors alters the transient response of the system. The solution to the ESA problem via state feedback for multivariable systems has been considered by many researchers in the last three decades (Andry et al., 1983; Askarpour and Owens, 1999; Clarke et al., 2003; Duan, 1993, 2003; Fahmy and O'Reilly, 1982, 1983; Fahmy and Tantawy, 1984; Porter and D’Azzo, 1978a,b; White, 1995).

Over the past few years, a considerable number of publications have been concerned with the derivative feedback control problem for linear control systems (Abdelaziz, 2007, 2009, 2010; Abdelaziz and Valášek, 2004, 2005a,b; Assuncao et al., 2007; Duan et al., 2005; Kwak et al., 2002a,b; Lewis and Syrmos, 1991; Reithmeier and Leitmann, 2003). The researchers have recognized the importance of using derivative feedback on diverse practical engineering fields, such as vibration suppression in mechanical systems and flexible structures where the accelerometer is the only sensor. In the past, the velocity and displacement were obtained using the integration process. Consequently, the bias in acceleration measurement can also reduce the integration accuracy that negatively affects the desired performance. Therefore, emphasis has been placed recently on the development of the controllers to control these systems using derivative feedback.

The derivative feedback is utilized to solve numerous practical control problems, such as those arising in vibration absorber systems (Abdelaziz, 2007, 2009, 2010; Abdelaziz and Valášek, 2004, 2005a,b; Assuncao et al., 2007), control of a cantilever beam (Kwak et al., 2002a), landing gear components (Kwak et al., 2002b), control of bridge cable vibration (Duan et al., 2005), and car wheel suspension system (Assuncao et al., 2007; Reithmeier and Leitmann, 2003). In earlier studies, the optimal controller and estimator via state-derivative feedback have proposed linear systems that have nonsingular state matrices (Kwak et al., 2002a,b). The pole placement technique has extended for designing the state-derivative feedback controllers for multi-input and single-input linear systems (Abdelaziz and Valášek, 2004, 2005b). Dynamical state-derivative feedback controllers have been designed to achieve the stabilization for time-invariant and time-varying linear systems.

In a more recent study, the optimal output-derivative feedback controller has been derived for linear time-invariant continuous systems (Abdelaziz, 2010). Furthermore, the solution to the robust pole assignment problem has been presented for continuous multi-inputlinear systems using state-derivative feedback (Abdelaziz, 2009). The necessary conditions for such a solution to exist are introduced. Moreover, the freedom available to assign eigenvectors for an arbitrary self-conjugate set of eigenvalues using state-derivative feedback is investigated. In addition, an efficient pole assignment solution is proposed for continuous single-input linear systems via state-derivative feedback (Abdelaziz, 2007). Assuncao et al. (2007) have proposed a linear-matrix-inequalities (LMI)-based control design of state-derivative feedback for multi-input linear systems. As far as the problem of eigenstructure assignment is concerned, there have been a few studies reported (Abdelaziz, 2009; Abdelaziz and Valášek, 2005a). The ESA via state-derivative feedback is introduced in Abdelaziz and Valášek (2005a) when the state matrix is nonsingular, while the generality of the solution for multivariable singular state matrices has still not been obtained.

The main contribution in this paper is to introduce a straightforward design procedure that solves the ESA problem for multi-input linear systems via state-derivative feedback. Control systems which have nonsingular and singular state matrices are investigated. Parametric expressions for the feedback gains and the right eigenvector matrices are established in terms of the closed-loop eigenvalues and a group of free vectors. Both the closed-loop eigenvalues and these groups of parameters can be properly chosen to produce a closed-loop system with some additional desired system specifications. Furthermore, a composite performance index is proposed to utilize the available degrees-of-freedom (d.f.) to obtain the robust solution. Consequently, the problem of robust eigenvalue assignment (EVA) is considered and an effective method that finds the robust controller is obtained. Finally, it should be pointed out that the stability problem via state-derivative feedback is more complicated than that for state feedback because it requires considering not only stability, but also regularity of the closed-loop system.

The outline of this paper is as follows: in the next section, the ESA problem using state-derivative feedback is formulated. Moreover, the necessary conditions, which ensure solvability, are presented. Accordingly, the robust EVA problem using state-derivative feedback is also formulated. Section 3 presents the parametric solution to the ESA problem. Furthermore, section 4 deals with a novel procedure for solving the robust EVA problem. An illustrative example and simulation results are studied in section 5. Conclusions follow in section 6.

sec.title: 2. Problem formulation
sec.p: Consider a continuous time-invariant multivariable linear system (1)x·(t)=Ax(t)+Bu(t),x(t0)=x0 where x·(t)∈ℝn is the state-derivative vector, x(t)∈ℝn is the state vector, u(t)∈ℝm is the control input vector, A∈ℝn×n is the state matrix and B∈ℝn×m is the input matrix. The fundamental assumptions imposed on the system are:
Assumption 1. The real pair (A, B) is completely controllable, that is, rank (λoIn – A : B) = n, ∀ λo∈ℂ, where In is the n × n identity matrix
Assumption 2. rank(B) = m.
Consider the following state-derivative feedback control (2)u(t)=-Kx·(t),K∈Rm×n
The state-derivative gain matrix K is computed such that the closed-loop system is asymptotically stable; (3)x·(t)=Acx(t),Ac=(In+BK)-1A
The poles of the closed-loop system are the rootsofthe following characteristic equation det(λ(In+BK)-A)=0.

Throughout the paper we assume that the term (In + BK) has a full rank to guarantee the existence and uniqueness of solution for a design system. Then the gain K is restricted to ensure that (In + BK) is always nonsingular.

Let Γ = {λi∈ℂ, i = 1,…,€r, 1 ≤ r ≤ n} be a set of desired self-conjugate eigenvalues, where r is the number of distinct eigenvalues, and denote the algebraic and geometric multiplicity of the ith eigenvalue λi by mi and qi, respectively, (1 ≤ qi ≤ mi). The length of qi chains of generalized eigenvectors with λi are denoted by pij, (€j = 1,…, qi). Then in the Jordan canonical form of the closed-loop matrix, there are qi blocks associated with the ith eigenvalue λi of orders pij. It is satisfying that Σi=1 r Σj=1 qi pij = n.

Further, denote the relative right eigenvector chains associated with eigenvalue λi by vij,k∈ℂn, i = 1,…,€r, j = 1,…,€qi, k = 1,…,€pij, and the following relations can be obtained (4)(In+BK)-1Avij,k=λivij,k+vij,k-1,vij,0=0,∀i,j,k

The notations for right eigenvectors are defined as: V(V1,…,Vr)∈Cn×n,Vi≜(Vi1,…,Viqi)∈ℂn×mi, Vij≜(vij,1,…,vij,pij)∈ℂn×pij where Vi contains all right eigenvectors and generalized eigenvectors associated with the eigenvalue λi. Equation (4) can be reformulated in a matrix form as (5)(In+BK)-1AV=VΛ where Λ∈ℂn×n is in Jordan canonical form which is formed by the desired eigenvalues Γ.
Now, we can formulate the ESA problem via state-derivative feedback as follows:

ESA problem: Given system (1) satisfying assumptions 1 and 2, and the desired self-conjugate set Γ, finda parameterization of all the state-derivative gains K and the right eigenvector matrices V satisfying equation (5).
Now, it is essential to recall the necessary conditions which ensure solvability via state-derivative feedback (Abdelaziz, 2009).
Lemma 1: The pole assignment problem via state-derivative feedback for the system (1) is solvable for any arbitrary self-conjugate closed-loop sets Γ, if the following conditions are met.

list-item.p: The pair (A, B) is completely controllable
If A is nonsingular, then the closed-loop system matrix is also nonsingular and all the assigned self-conjugate eigenvalues set Γ should be non-zero

If A is singular with rank(A) = n–c, 1 ≤ c < n, then the closed-loop system matrix is also singular and any arbitrary n–1 self-conjugate set {λ1,…,€λn–1} can be assigned, while one eigenvalue should be zero
The term (In + BK) is nonsingular

Rosenbrock’s inequalities, which involve the controllability indices μ1,…, μm of the system (decreasingly ordered by magnitude) can be assigned the desired invariant polynomials ψ1(λ),…,€ψm(λ) (decreasingly ordered by magnitude), which satisfies Σj=1m∑ deg ψj(λ) = n, if and only if (6)∑i=j mψj(λ)≤∑i=j mμj, j=1,…,m are satisfied and equality holds when j = 1 (single-input system).

sec.p: In addition, the feedback gain K is unique when ker(B) = 0.
Proof: See (Abdelaziz, 2009). ▪
Two remarks should be given on the aforementioned lemma.

Remark 1: The limits in altering the eigenstructureoflinear systems using state-derivative feedback are presented here as Rosenbrock’s inequalities. As weare interested not only in assigning the location of the poles but also their multiplicities, it appears that the freedom in modifying the dynamics of the system is limited by the values of the controllability indices of the system (μj, j = 1,…,€m). This result is analogous to the famous Rosenbrock theorem for linear systems using state feedback (Rosenbrock, 1970). There already exist a lot of different proofs for the Rosenbrock theorem via state feedback (Dickinson, 1974; Flamm, 1980).

Remark 2: For any controllable single-input system (m = 1), the solution is unique since ker(B) = 0. In this case there is no eigenvector assignment freedom and the eigenvalues alone can uniquely determine the feedback system dynamic matrix. Otherwise, for any controllable multi-input systems (m > 1), there are infinitely many solutions to the feedback gain, whenever a solution exists. Consequently, it is obvious to see whether or not the closed-loop system is robust against the system parameter perturbation. This issue becomes very significant when the system model is not sufficiently precise or the system is subject to parameter uncertainty.
Now, the following robust eigenvalue assignment problem via state-derivative feedback is presented as:

Robust EVA problem: Given system (1) satisfying assumptions 1 and 2, and the desired self-conjugate set Γ, find the state-derivative gain K and the right eigenvector matrix V satisfying equation (5), such that conditioning and robustness of the eigenproblem are optimized.
The aim now is to develop simple algorithms, which solve the aforementioned problems, for the nonsingular and singular state matrices.

sec.title: 3. Eigenstructure assignment
sec.p: In this section, the complete parametric solution to the ESA problem for nonsingular and singular state matrices is introduced. Since the term (In + BK) is assumed invertible, then equation (4) can be reformulated as (7)(λiIn-A)vij,k+λiBwij,k=-vij,k-1-Bwij,k-1,vij,0=0, i=1,…,r, j=1,…,qi, k=1,…,pij where the associated vectors (8)wij,k=Kvij,k∈ℂm,wij,0=0,i=1,…,r,j=1,…,qi, k=1,…,pij are defined as W≜(W1,…,Wr)∈ℂm×n,Wi≜(Wi1,…,Wiqi)∈ℂm×mi, Wij≜(wij,1,…,Wij,pij)∈ℂm×pij Thus, equation (7) can be expressed by (9)(λiIn-A:λiB)(vij,kwij,k)=-(In:B)(vij,k-1wij,k-1), vij,0=0,wij,0=0, ∀i,j,k.

Finally, from equation (8) a parametric solution to the state-derivative feedback gain is (10)K=WV-1 provided that V is nonsingular. Then the feedback gain is parameterized directly in terms of the eigenstructure of the closed-loop system.
Remark 3: If the desired poles are distinct (mi = qi = 1, r = n), then equation (9) can be reformulated as (11)(λiIn-A:λiB)(viwi)=0,i=1,…,n.

There are many solutions to this equation and hencemany eigenvectors vi and associated vectors wi for each eigenvalue λi, i = 1,…, n. Then, ker(λiIn-A:λiB)=range(MiLi),i=1,…,n where Mi∈ℂn×m and Li∈ℂm×m. It follows that (12)(viwi)=(MiLi)fi, i=1,…,n where fi∈ℂm are free vectors and represent the d.f. available to assign the right eigenvectors vi associated to λi. Since vi can be scaled by any non-zero vector, then each fi provides m−1 d.f.. Finally, the explicit parametric expression for state-derivative gain can be expressed by (13)K=(L1f1,…,Lnfn)(M1f1,…,Mnfn)-1
Here, the vectors fi must be chosen so that (M1€f1,…, Mn€€fn) is invertible.

Below, we will obtain the general solutions for vectors vij,k and wij,k that involve free vectors. We remark that developing a parametric solution to this problem is useful in that one can then think about solving other important variations of the problem, such as the robust EVA problem by exploiting freedom of these vectors.

sec.title: 3.1. State matrix A is nonsingular
sec.p: Let us take the case when the state matrix A is nonsingular and the parametric solutions for the vectors vij,k and wij,k are obtained using the technique from Abdelaziz and Valášek (2005a).

Theorem 1: Let the pair (A, B) be controllable, where A is nonsingular, and a non-zero desired self-conjugate poles Γ, then all solutions of equation (9), vij,k and wij,k, are given by: (14)vij,k=-Qi,11Pi(vij,k-1+Bwij,k-1)+Qi,12fij,k,vij,0=0,∀i,j,kwij,k=-Qi,21Pi(vij,k-1+Bwij,k-1)+Qi,22fij,k,wij,0=0,∀i,j,k

Otherwise, if the closed-loop eigenvalues λi, i = 1,…,€r are not known a priori, then the solutions are obtained by (15)(vij,kwij,k)=(N(λi)D(λi))fij,k+ddλ(N(λi)D(λi))fij,k-1+…+1(k-1)!d k-1dλk-1(N(λi)D(λi))fij,1,∀i,j,k where fij,k∈ℂm are arbitrarily free vectors, Pi∈ℂn×n and Qi€∈€ℂ(n+m)×(n+m) are matrices satisfying (16)Pi(λiIn-A:λiB)Qi=(In:0),QiΔ=(Qi,11Qi,12Qi,21Qi,22), Qi,11∈ℂn×n,Qi,21∈ℂm×n,i=1,…,r.
Further, N(λ) and D(λ) are polynomial matrices of dimensions n×m and m×m, respectively, satisfying (17)(λIn-A)N(λ)+λBD(λ)=0
Proof: See Abdelaziz and Valášek (2005a). ▪
Based on the above, a procedure for solving the ESA problem can be given as follows.
Algorithm 1 (ESA when A is nonsingular)
Given system (1) satisfying assumptions 1 and 2, and a non-zero self-conjugate set Γ.

list-item.p: Compute the matrices Pi and Qi (i = 1, ..., r) satisfying equation (16) or compute the polynomial matrices N(λ) and D(λ) satisfying equation (17).
Choose arbitrarily the non-zero vectors fij,k∈ℂm, ∀i, j, k, in such a way that fi2j,k *=fi1j,k⇔λi2 *=λi1
Calculate the vectors vij,k and wij,k, ∀i, j, k, using equations (14) or (15) and construct the matrices V and W satisfying det(V) ≠ 0.
Compute the real feedback gain using K = WV−1

sec.title: 3.2. State matrix A is singular
sec.p: In this section, we will propose a novel algorithm when the state matrix A is singular. This work is based on the use of the technique of a reduced-order system obtained by the Schur decomposition of the system matrix (Abdelaziz, 2009). Accordingly, the two blocks associated respectively with the non-zero and zero open-loop eigenvalues can be obtained. We will make the following assumption throughout this paper (Abdelaziz, 2009, 2010).
Assumption 3. The multiplicity of the zero eigenvalues of A is equal to one.
The assumption made guarantees that the non-zero block of dimension n–1.
The problem can be solved by reducing A into real Schur form (RSF) using the orthogonal transformations. In this way, consider the following state transformation
x(t) = Ũz(t), z(t)∈ℝn
where Ũ ≜ (u~ : U)∈ℝn×n is orthonormal, u~ ∈ℝn, U∈ℝn×(n–1). So that the resulting open-loop system has the form (18)z·(t)=Azz(t)+Bzu(t), Az=U~TAU~=(u~TAu~u~TAUUTAu~UTAU),Bz=U~TB=(u~TBUTB)
where the submatrix UTAU∈ℝ(n–1)×(n–1) is nonsingular, UTB∈ℝ(n–1)×m and Ũ€TAu~ = 0. Moreover, if the real pair (A, B) is controllable, then the subsystem pair (UTAU, UTB) is controllable as well.
Taking the state-derivative feedback control (19)u(t)=-F~z·(t),K=F~U~T,F~∈ℝm×n.
In this way, the feedback gain matrix can be represented by (20)F~=(0m×n:F),K=FUT,F∈ℝm×(n-1)

Substituting equations (19) and (20) into equation (18) yields z·(t)=(1u~TBF0In-1+UTBF)-1Azz(t) or, (21)z·(t)=(u~TAu~×0(In-1+UTBF)-1UTAU)z(t) where × stands for unspecified matrices. Hence, the eigenvalues of the closed-loop system are the eigenvalues of (In–1 + UTBF)–1UTAU and one zero value. If the pair (A, B) is controllable, then the procedure for nonsingular state systems can be applied to the subsystem (UTAU, UTB), which has non-zero poles.

Firstly, let the set of prespecified closed-loop eigenvalues Γ be partitioned into two subsets as: Γ = {Ω,0}∈ℂ, such that Ω = {λi∈ℂ, i = 1,…, r–1, 1 ≤ r ≤ n–1} be a desired set of non-zero, self-conjugate, eigenvalues. Also, v∧ij,k∈ℂn–1, i = 1,…, r–1, j = 1,…, qi, k = 1,…, pij, is the closed-loop right eigenvector chains corresponding to λi. Then the following relations can be obtained for the subsystem (UTAU, UTB)
(In–1 + UTBK)–1UTAUv∧ij,k = λiv∧ij,k+v∧ij,k-1, v∧ij,0 = 0, i = 1, ..., r–1, j = 1, ..., qi, k = 1, ..., pij.

Thus, the above equation can be reformulated as (22)(λiIn-1-UTAU:λiUTB)(v∧ij,kw∧ij,k) =-(In-1:UTB)(v∧ij,k-1w∧ij,k-1),v∧ij,0=0, ∀i,j,k where the associated vectors are (23)w∧ij,k=Fv∧ij,k∈ℂm,w∧ij,0=0,i=1,…,r-1,j=1,…,qi,k=1,…,pij.
Here, the eigenvectors and the associated vectors for the subsystem (UTAU, UTB) are defined as:
ĥ ≜ (ĥ1,…, ĥr-1)∈ℂ(n–1)×(n–1) , Vi ≜ (Vi1,…, Viqi) ∈ ℂ(n − 1) × mi,Vij ≜ (vij,1, …, vij,pij ) → ℂ(n-1)×pij,
Ŵ ≜ (Ŵ1,…, Ŵr–1)∈ℂm×(n–1), Ŵi ≜ (Ŵi1,…,W∧iqi) m×mi∈ℂ, Ŵij ≜ (ŵij,1,…, w∧ij,pij ) m×pij∈ℂ.

Consequently, equation (22) can be reformulated as (24)(In-1+UTBF)-1UTAUV∧=V∧Ψ where Ψ is in Jordan canonical form which is formed by the desired non-zero eigenvalues Ω. Subsequently, one can obtain (25)In-1+UTBF=UTAUV∧Ψ-1V∧-1
Once more, the term (In–1 + UTBF) is nonsingular if both the matrices Ψ and V∧ are nonsingular.

Since UTAU is nonsingular and Ω is a non-zero set of desired poles, so the results of Theorem 1 can be applied for the subsystem (UTAU, UTB). Consequently, all the solutions of equation (22), v∧ij,k and ŵij,k, are given by: (26)v∧ij,k=-Q~i,11P~i(v∧ij,k-1+UTBw∧ij,k-1)+Q~i,12 fij,k,v∧ij,0=0, ∀i,j,k,w∧ij,k=-Q~i,21P~i(v∧ij,k-1+UTBw∧ij,k-1)+Q~i,22 fij,k,w∧ij,0=0, ∀i,j,k.

Otherwise, if the desired closed-loop eigenvalues λi, i = 1,…, r–1 are not known a priori, then all the solutions are obtained by (27)(v∧ij,kw∧ij,k)=(N~(λi)D~(λi))fij,k+ddλ(N~(λi)D~(λi))fij,k-1+…+1(k-1)!d k-1dλk-1(N~(λi)D~(λi))fij,1, ∀i,j,k where fij,k∈ℂm, ∀ i, j, k, are arbitrarily free vectors satisfying the following two constraints:
Constraint 1. λi2 *=λi1⇔fi2j,k *=fi1j,k, i = 1,…, r–1, j = 1,…, qi, k = 1,…, pij;
Constraint 2. det(V∧ ) ≠ 0.

Constraint 1 ensures that the feedback gain F is real, while Constraint 2 ensures that the assigned eigenvectors are linearly independent. The free parameters fij,kinequations (26) and (27) represent the degrees-of-freedom available in the controller design for multivariable systems.

The matrices P~i ∈ℂ(n–1)×(n–1) and Q~i ∈ℂ(n+m–1)×(n+m–1) satisfying (28)P~i(λiIn-1-UTAU:λiUTB)Q~i=(In-1:0),=1,…,r-1 where Q~iΔ=(Q~i,11Q~i,12Q~i,21Q~i,22),Q~i,11∈ℂ(n-1)×(n-1),Q~i,12∈ℂ(n-1)×m,Q~i,21∈ℂm×(n-1)andQ~i,22∈ℂm×m,i=1,…,r-1.
Further, N~(λ) and D~(λ) are polynomial matrices of dimensions (n–1)×m and m×m, respectively, satisfying (29)(λIn-1-UTAU)N~(λ)+λUTBD~(λ)=0.
From equation (23), we can obtain that Ŵ = FV∧ . So, the state-derivative feedback gain is (30)F=W∧V∧-1 (31)K=W∧V∧-1UT.

As a result, all non-zero eigenvalues can be altered by the state-derivative feedback. This gives complete and explicit parametric solutions with complete and explicit freedom of the ESA via state-derivative feedback. The solution is expressed by the desired eigenvalues and a group of free vectors fij,k. By especially choosing the free vectors, solutions with desired properties can be obtained.
Remark 4: For distinct eigenvalues, then one can obtain the eigenvectors and the associated vectors as (32)v∧i=Q~i,12fi,w∧i=Q~i,22 fi,i=1,…,n-1 or (33)v∧i=N~(λi)fi,w∧i=D~(λi)fi,i=1,…,n-1
Consequently, the parametric feedback gain can be expressed by (34)K=(Q~1,22 f1,…,Q~n-1,22 fn-1)(Q~1,12 f1,…,Q~n-1,12 fn-1)-1UT or (35)K=(D~(λ1)f1,…,D~(λn-1)fn-1)(N~(λ1)f1,…,N~(λn-1)fn-1)-1UT
The preceding formulation can be summarized as an algorithm.
Algorithm 2 (ESA when A is singular)
Given system (1) satisfying assumptions 1, 2 and 3, and n–1 non-zero self-conjugate set Ω.

list-item.p: Reduce system (1) into the real Schur form as (18) and obtain the submatrices UTAU and UTB.
Compute the matrices P~i and Q~i (i = 1, ..., r–1) satisfying (28) or compute the polynomial matrices N~(λ) and D~(λ) satisfying (29).
Choose arbitrarily the non-zero vectors fij,k∈ℂm, ∀ i, j, k, in such a way that fi2j,k *=fi1j,k⇔λi2 *=λi1.

Calculate the vectors v∧ij,k and ŵij,k, ∀i, j, k, using (26) or (27) and construct the matricesV∧ and Ŵ. If det(V∧ ) = 0, then return to Step 3 and select different parameter vectors fij,k until V∧ is nonsingular.
Compute the real feedback gain using K = ŴV∧-1 UT.

sec.p: The main step of the aforementioned algorithm is Step 2. One comment on the implementation of Step 2 is considered.

Because controllability criterion of the subsystem (UTAU, UTB) implies that all the rows of (λIn–1 – UTAU : UTB) are linearly independent, then (λIn–1 – UTAU : λUTB) has a complete rank for all values ofnon-zero λ. Consequently, the singular value decomposition (SVD) can be applied to (λiIn–1 – UTAU : λiUTB) as (36)(λiIn-1-UTAU:λiUTB)=Xi(Σi:0)Q~i *,
Σi = diag{σi1, σi2,…,σi,n–1}, i = 1,…, r–1,

where Xi∈ℂ(n–1)×(n–1), Q~i∈ℂ(n+m–1)×(n+m–1) are orthogonal and Σi∈ℂ(n–1)×(n–1) is nonsingular diagonal matrix, where σi1 ≥ σi2 ≥ … ≥ σi,n–1 > 0. Here * denotes complex conjugate and transpose. Pre-multiplying equation (36) by Σi–1XiT and post-multiplying by Q~i,one can obtain equation (28), where P~i=(1/σi1001/σi,n-1)Xi T,i=1,…,r-1.
It is well-known that the SVD is numerically stable.
Hence it is easy to verify the following equation (λiIn-1-UTAU:λiUTB)(Q~i,12Q~i,22) =Xi(Σi:0)Q~i *(Q~i,12Q~i,22) =Xi(Σi:0)(0Im)=0,i=1,…,r-1.
One can see that this equation states that the columns of (Q~i,12Q~i,22) form a set of orthogonal bases for ker(λiIn–1 – UTAU : λiUTB).

Alternatively, the RQ decomposition of the matrix (λiIn–1 – UTAU : λiUTB) can be utilized (37)(λiIn-1-UTAU:λiUTB)=(Ri:0)Q~i *,i=1,…,r-1 where Q~i is orthogonal and Ri∈ℂ(n–1)×(n–1) is nonsingular. Pre-multiplying this equation by Ri–1 and post-multiplying by Q~i, one can obtain equation (28), where P~i = Ri–1.
Further, one can obtain the matrices Q~i,11=(In-1:0)Q~i(In-10),Q~i,12=(In-1:0)Q~i(0Im),Q~i,21=(0:Im)Q~i(In-10),Q~i,22=(0:Im)Q~i(0Im)

Otherwise, if the desired eigenvalues λi, i = 1,…, r–1 are not known a priori, then the augmented matrix (38)H=(In-1λIn-1-UTAU:λUTB0In+m-1) can be changed into the form of (39)H∧=(P~(λ)In-1:00Q~(λ)),Q~(λ)=(×N~(λ)×D~(λ)) by applying a series of row elementary transformations within the upper n–1 rows and a series of column elementary transformations within the last n+m–1 columns, matrices P~(λ) and Q~(λ) in the final transformed matrix Ĥ are unimodular. Accordingly, Q~(λ) can be partitioned to find the polynomial matrices N~(λ) and D~(λ) .

The drawback of the direct ESA technique is that the synthesis procedure does not guarantee stability robustness to parameter variations in the plant dynamics. Therefore, we will propose the robust EVA design that optimizes the performance robustness while constraining the desired eigenvalues.

sec.title: 4. Robust eigenvalue assignment
sec.p: In many practical problems, there often exist parameter variations or perturbations in the design system. Additionally, the presence of uncertainty in the model severely affects the performance and stability of the closed-loop system. Consequently, the robust problem is considered and an effective method that finds a robust controller can be obtained. The robust EVA methods try to utilize the freedom over the closed-loop eigenvectors to arrange them such that the closed-loop system becomes insensitive to parameter variations. It is shown that if the eigenvectors of a system are assigned to match exactly a set of mutually orthogonal vectors, then the corresponding eigenvalues will have the minimum sensitivity to the perturbations and parameter variations (Abdelaziz, 2009). To utilize the available freedom for multi-input systems to obtain an optimal solution is next discussed. The performance index can be defined in many different ways depending on the chosen robustness measure. In the following, three robustness measures are discussed and two algorithms are suggested to design the robust controller.

sec.title: 4.1. Condition number
sec.p: For an insensitive solution, the eigenvectors are chosen to be as mutually orthogonal as possible. There are some sensitivity measures, which produce nearly orthogonal eigenvectors (Byers and Nash, 1989; Kautsky et al., 1985). The spectral condition number of the closed-loop eigenvector matrix is the most widely accepted measure of eigenvalue sensitivity (Golub and Van Loan, 1989; Stewart and Sun, 1990). A measure of the sensitivity of a solution is the conditioning of the closed-loop system right eigenvectors given by
where || . || denotes the Euclidean norm.
Other results for the state-derivative feedback are the following (Abdelaziz, 2009):

The norm of the state-derivative feedback gain matrix K satisfies (40)||K||≤(σm(B))-1(κ(V)||A||max1≤i≤n{|λi -1|}+1) where σm(B) denotes the mth (smallest) singular value of matrix B and | . | is the modulus value.
The norm of the transient response x(t) satisfies (41)||x(t)||≤κ(V)||x0||max1≤i≤n{|ei λit|}
It is worth observing from equations (40) and (41) that, a smaller κ(V) can generally imply lower control gain and a smoother response. The aim now is to select V as orthogonal as possible.

The robust EVA problem is to select a set of thedesired eigenvalues λi, i = 1,…, n, and a linearly independent eigenvector matrix V which minimize κ(V). Consequently, the performance function can be expressed by (42)J1=||V||||V-1||.

Another possible measure is the Frobenius condition number κF(V) ≜ || V ||F || V–1 ||F, where || . ||F denotes the Frobenius norm. Based on this, Byers and Nash (1989) have proposed the following robustness measure: (43)J2=‖V‖F2+‖V−1‖F2 which can be utilized to obtain the feedback gain.

sec.title: 4.2. Feedback gain
sec.p: Another minimization problem using state-derivative feedback can be considered that is based on the minimization of the norm of feedback gain (44)J3=||K||.

This represents the amount of energy required for the corresponding control action. A reduction of gain || K || results in the average magnitude of control being reduced; therefore, it is an attractive design objective.

sec.title: 4.3. Composite performance index
sec.p: The trade-off between J1, J2 and J3 can be made by forming the composite performance indices as: (45)J=αJ1+βJ2+γJ3 where α, β and γ∈[0, 1] are positive scalars representing the weighting factors on J1, J2 and J3, respectively.

One can observe that the feedback gain K is calculated using the matrices V and W. Moreover, V is determined by the free vectors fij,k. Consequently, the robust EVA problem using state-derivative feedback can be explicitly expressed by the following optimization problem: (46)minfij,kJ
Subject to: AV = (In + BK)VΛ, det(V) ≠ 0, and λi2 *=λi1⇔fi2j,k *=fi1j,k, ∀ i, j, k.
Now, the following algorithms are suggested to design the robust EVA controller.
Algorithm 3: (Robust EVA when A is nonsingular)
Given system (1) satisfying assumptions 1 and 2, and a non-zero self-conjugate set Γ.

list-item.p: Compute the matrices Pi and Qi (i = 1, ..., r) satisfying (16) or compute the polynomial matrices N(λ) and D(λ) satisfying (17).
Choose a randomly generated vector fij,k, ∀i, j, k, satisfying det(V) ≠ 0.
Compute the optimal vectors fij,k, ∀i, j, k, satisfying fi2j,k *=fi1j,k⇔λi2 *=λi1, which minimize the corresponding composite performance index (46).
Construct the matrices V and W based on the parameters determined in Step 3 and satisfying det(V) ≠ 0.
Compute the real feedback gain using K = WV–1.

sec.p: Algorithm 4: (Robust EVA when A is singular)
Given system (1) satisfying assumptions 1, 2 and 3, and n–1 non-zero self-conjugate set Ω.

list-item.p: Reduce system (1) into the real Schur form as (18) and obtain the submatrices UTAU and UTB.
Compute the matrices P~i and Q~i (i = 1,…, r–1) satisfying (28) or compute the polynomial matrices N~(λ) and D~(λ) satisfying (29).
Choose a randomly generated vector fij,k, ∀i, j, k, satisfying det(V∧€) ≠ 0.
Compute the optimal vectors fij,k, ∀i, j, k, satisfying fi2j,k *=fi1j,k⇔λi2 *=λi1, which minimize the composite performance index (46).
Construct the matrices V∧ and Ŵ based on the parameters determined in Step 4 and satisfying det(V∧€) ≠ 0.
Compute the real feedback gain using K = ŴV∧-1 UT.

sec.p: It should be emphasized that there are more than onelocal minimum of the performance index J. Furthermore, the choice of the initial values of the free parameters fij,k play an important role for obtainingthe optimal solution. Therefore, several initial parameters should be considered. In the next section, an illustrative numerical example is presented.

sec.title: 5. Simulation results
sec.p:
To demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed technique, this section considers the synthesis of controllers for the vibration absorber system shown in Figure 1. The system dynamic equation can be described by the state-space form using the state vector x(t) = (x1, x2, x·1, x·2)T as: x·=(00100001-k1c1-k2c2-b1c1-b2c2-k1c2-k2c1-b1c2-b2c1)x +(0000c1c2c2c1)(u1u2) Figure 1.
Vibration absorber system.

where, c1 =1m+L2I, c2 =1m-L2I, m and I represent the mass and inertia of the mass, k1 and k2 are the spring constants, b1 and b2 are the damper constants, x1 and x2 are the mass displacement from both sides, ϕ is the inclination angle of the mass with the horizontal, 2L is the distance between two supporting points, and u1 and u2 are the control inputs. For this system, the accelerations from both sides of the mass can be measured directly via accelerometers (x··1(t), x··2(t)) and the velocity components can then be obtained from integration (x·1(t), x·2(t)). Consequently, the state-derivative vector can be constructed as: x·(t) = (x·1, x·2, x··1, x··2)T.

sec.title: 5.1. State-matrix is nonsingular
sec.p: The system parameters are taken as: m = 10 kg, I = 1 Kg.m2, L = 1 m, k1 = 500 N/m, k2 = 600 N/m, b1 = 10 N.s/m and b2 = 15 N.s/m. Then the state matrix A is nonsingular and the open-loop eigenvalues are located at {–12.5390 ± 30.7077i, –1.2110 ± 10.3733i}. Moreover, the system is controllable and the system controllability indices are μ1 = 2 and μ2 = 2. Suppose that the eigenvalues of the closed-loop system are selected as Γ = {–20 ± 10i, –30, –40}. So, the necessary conditions of Lemma 1 are satisfied. Below, numerical simulations are carried out to verify the proposed control methods presented in this paper for controlling vibration of the model.

sec.title: 5.1.1. Eigenstructure assignment
sec.p: Since the open-loop state matrix A is nonsingular, then Algorithm 1 will be utilized to obtain the state-derivative feedback gain. Applying the SVD to matrix (λiIn – A : λiB), then one can easily obtain matrices Pi and Qi, i = 1,…,4, satisfying (16). In this simulation, the MATLAB function ‘svd.m’ is employed to obtain the SVD. Specially choosing the free parameter vectors as: f1=f2=(31), f3=(11), f4=(32)
Consequently, the state-derivative feedback gain is K=WV-1=(76.1801136.2410-0.87192.8288-27.0451-35.4161-2.9416-4.3541)

Accordingly, the norm of closed-loop eigenvector matrix || V || is 1.8973, the conditioning of closed-loop system κ(V) is 3219.1463 and the gain norm || K || is 162.2622. Here, rank(In + BK) = 4.00. In addition, the accuracy of the computed closed-loop eigenvalues isillustrated by the errors which are computed as 1.0e–11*{–0.0306 ± 0.2384i, –0.7244, 0.0810}. This verified that the eigenvalues of the closed-loop matrix are correctly placed. In addition, the response of closed-loop system x(t), control inputs u(t) and state-derivatives x·(t) for the initial state conditions x(t0) = [–0.01, 0.01, –0.02, 0.02]T are displayed in Figure 2. Figure 2.
The system response, control inputs and state-derivatives for non-robust case.

sec.title: 5.1.2. Robust EVA solution
sec.p: Since A is nonsingular, then Algorithm 3 is utilized to obtain the robust feedback gain. Here, the non-uniqueness of the eigenvector matrix is exploited to optimize the robustness of the system. In this simulation, the ‘fminunc.m’ unconstrained minimization function available in the Optimization Toolbox of MATLAB has been employed to minimize the performance index J. In the following, the comparisons between four cases are discussed.
Case 1: For the same model parameters, the initial values of the free parameters are taken as: f01=f02=(23), f03=(32), f04=(12)
Then the optimal parameter vectors based on the minimization of the condition number J1 (α = 1, β = 0, γ = 0) are obtained as: f1=f2=103*(0.14190.2322), f3=103*(0.19580.1672),f4=103*(-9.91251.6651).
So, the robust state-derivative feedback gain matrixis K=(23.1059-3.1911-2.2199-2.309919.578328.2730-1.6350-1.8763)

In order to confirm the validity of the proposed method, the calculated parameters for this case are ||V || = 1.4914, κ(V) = 146.4633 and || K || = 36.8658, which are smaller than previously obtained for the non-robust solution. Furthermore, the resulting errors in closed-loop eigenvalues are obtained as: 1.0e–12*{–0.0142 ± 0.0693i, 0.0675, 0.1492}. The simulation results of the response of the closed-loop system, control inputs and state-derivatives for the same initial states x0 are shown in Figure 3. It can be seen that there are considerable differences between the response, control inputs and state-derivatives of the robust solution compared with the non-robust one (Figure 2). The robust solution obtains a smaller transient response and control input. Figure 3.
The system response, control inputs and state-derivatives for robust eignevalue assessment (α = 1, β = 0, γ = 0).
Case 2: In this case the optimal parameter vectors based on the minimization of the gain norm J3 (α = 0, β = 0, γ = 1) are obtained as: f1=f2=(2.6974-0.7767), f3=(3.57640.3617),f4=(1.36380.2825)

Consequently, it can be verified that || V || = 1.9872, κ(V) = 1540.2057 and || K || = 25.7375. Here, the gain norm is reduced from 162.2622 to 25.7375 compared with the non-robust case. This is the lowest gain norm compared with the other cases. The errors in poles are obtained as 1.0e–11*{–0.0327 ± 0.0369i, –0.0604, 0.4398}. The simulation results of the closed-loop system for the same initial states x0 are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
The system response, control inputs and state-derivatives for robust eigenvalue assessment (α = 0, β = 0, γ = 1).
Case 3: In this case the minimization of J2 (α = 0, β = 1, γ = 0) is presented. The optimal parameters are obtained as: f1=f2=(22.413313.1223), f3=(25.147628.4775),f4=(1.6726-11.7829)
Consequently, it is easy to obtain that ||€V€|| = 1.5711, κ(V) = 164.1858 and || K || = 35.7841. Also, the errors in closed-loop poles are 1.0e–13*{–0.1421 ± 0.2842i, 0.9948, 0.2842}.

Case 4: Finally, the minimization of the composite performance index J, with a scalar weights as (α = 0.50, β = 0.25, γ = 0.25), is illustrated. The optimal parameters are f1=f2=(13.703022.1479),f3=(29.727926.4111),f4=(10.7873-1.6709)

Accordingly, the following results are obtained basedon the computed vectors ||V || = 1.5091, κ(V) = 147.1601, || K || = 36.8610 and the errors in poles are 1.0e–13*{0.2842 ± 0.9948i, 0.8882, –0.2132}.

Finally, it is very important to study the sensitivity of the solution with respect to perturbations in the data in order to analyze the validity of the computed results and the robustness of the solution. Suppose that the mass m is perturbed to m + Δm = 10.1 kg and all the other model parameters are not changed. Consequently, the open-loop system matrices A and B are perturbed to A + ΔA and B + ΔB, where ΔA and ΔB are perturbedparameters. Accordingly, the perturbed closed-loop linear system can be described by the following equation (47)x·p(t)=(In+(B+ΔB)K)-1(A+ΔA)xp(t)
Consequently, the state and state-derivative error trajectories are denoted by (48)e(t)=x(t)-xp(t), (49)e·(t)=x·(t)-x·p(t).

For the non-robust solution and the four robust solutions, the corresponding eigenvalues of the perturbed closed-loop system {λ1p, …, λ4p} and the norm of errors in poles due to perturbation, are illustrated in Table 1. It is easy to observe that the closed-loop spectra are very far away from the desired ones for the non-robust solution. Moreover, the eigenvalues of the perturbed closed-loop system for robust solutions are considerably smaller compared with the non-robust one, particularly in Case 1. This clearly indicated that minimizing the condition number κ(V) generally gives smaller deviation from the nominal pole positions. Figures 5–9 describe the state error e(t) and state-derivative error ė (t) trajectories for all the non-robust and robust solutions with the same initial states x0. It is observed that the errors for robust solutions are considerably smaller compared with the non-robust one. This demonstrates that the proposed control method is robust against the parameter variation. Figure 5.
The state and state-derivative error trajectories using non-robust solution (nonsingular system). Figure 6.
The state and state-derivative error trajectories using robust solution of Case 1 (nonsingular system). Figure 7.
The state and state-derivative error trajectories using robust solution of Case 2 (nonsingular system). Figure 8.
The state and state-derivative error trajectories using robust solution of Case 3 (nonsingular system). Figure 9.
The state and state-derivative error trajectories using robust solution of Case 4 (nonsingular system). Table 1.
Eigenvalues of perturbed closed-loop system and the error norm
Solution κ(V) Eigenvalues of perturbed closed-loop system Error norm
Non-robust solution 3219.1463 –16.7645 ± 10.6769i, –24.6505, –77.5657 38.2316
Robust solutions Case 1 146.4633 –10.4479i ± 19.0051, –19.0051, –31.3284 2.2423
Case 2 1540.2057 –32.4005 ± 10.3756i, –19.4454 ± 9.7034i 16.7216
Case 3 164.1858 –19.0250 ± 10.4479i, –31.4761, –38.7654 2.4506
Case 4 147.1601 –18.9973 ± 10.4473i, –31.3594, –39.0690 2.2621

sec.title: 5.2. State-matrix is singular
sec.p: Below, the case of singular system matrix A is presented and the feedback gain is computed. If the value of the spring constant k1 is set zero and all the other parameters are not changed, then A is singular and the eigenvalues of the open-loop system are located at {0.00, −3.8112, –11.8444 ± 22.1230i}.

Consequently, the submatrices UTAU∈ℝ3×3 and UTB∈ℝ3×2 are obtained. It is clear that the eigenvalues of UTAU are all the non-zero eigenvalues of A, which are located at {–3.8112, –1.8444 ± 22.1230i}. Suppose that we want to place the eigenvalues of the closed-loop system as: Γ = {Ω, 0}, Ω = {–20 ± 10i, –30}. In what follows, several solutions to this problem are presented.

sec.title: 5.2.1. Eigenstructure Assignment
sec.p: Because A is singular, then Algorithm 2 is utilized to obtain the feedback gain. Here, the subsystem pair (UTAU, UTB) is controllable. First, applying the SVD to matrix (λiIn–1 – UTAU : λiUTB), one can easily obtain matrices P~i and Q~i, i = 1, 2, 3, satisfying equation (28). So, Q~i,12 and Q~i,22 (i = 1, 2, 3) are also obtained. Specially choosing the free parameter vectors satisfying Constraint 1 as:
Consequently, the eigenvector matrix and the associated matrix can be constructed as
From numerical simulation, the feedback gain is K=W∧V∧-1UT=(0.00-249.2619-1.5187-11.57390.00-20.8760-2.0657-3.8209)

Consequently, the norm of eigenvector matrix || V || is 1.4989, the conditioning of the closed-loop system κ(V) is 2017.2091 and the gain norm || K || is 250.4209. Further, the accuracy of computed closed-loop eigenvalues is illustrated by the errors which are 1.0e–11*{0.00, –0.6640 ± 0.0487i, 0.4746}. This verified that the eigenvalues of the closed-loop matrix are correctly placed.

sec.title: 5.2.2. Robust EVA solution
sec.p: In this simulation, since the state matrix A is singular then Algorithm 4 is utilized to obtain the robust state-derivative feedback gains. Again, the ‘fminunc.m’ unconstrained minimization function is employed to minimize the performance index J. Now, four cases are considered as follows.
Case 1: For the same example, the initial values of the free parameters are taken as: f01=f02=(32), f03=(31)

Consequently, the optimal parameter vectors based on the minimization of the condition number J1 (α = 1, β = 0, γ = 0) are f1=f2=(3.16126.4987),f3=(13.829411.8502) With these parameters, the corresponding gain is K=(0.002.5834-2.3886-2.23110.0031.3167-2.3437-1.6480)

It can be demonstrated that for this case ||€V€|| = 1.3484, κ(V) = 55.8857 and || K || = 31.5792, which are smaller than previously obtained for the non-robust solution. Here, the condition number is reduced from 2017.2091 to 55.8857 and the gain norm considerably decreases from 250.4209 to 31.5792. Furthermore, the resulting errors in the closed-loop eigenvalues are 1.0e–12*{0.00, –0.0995 ± 0.1439i, −0.6324}.

Case 2: The optimal parameter vectors based on the minimization of the norm of feedback gain J3 (α = 0, β = 0, γ = 1) are obtained as: f1=f2=(1.93543.4115),f3=(9.993118.0086) So, the gain is K=(0.0011.2936-1.9110-1.79710.002.6613-3.6773-3.0436)

Consequently, it can be verified that || V || = 1.6469, κ(V) = 240.5875 and || K || = 12.2293. Here, the gain norm is reduced from 250.4209 to 12.2293 compared with the non-robust solution. Furthermore, the errors in poles are 1.0e–11*{0.00, 0.1364 ± 0.0021i, –0.0438}.

Case 3: The optimal parameter vectors based on the minimization of J2 (α = 0, β = 1, γ = 0) are given as: f1=f2=(1.45013.7725), f3=(2.28962.3557) Then the feedback gain is K=(0.004.2422-2.3758-2.14910.0030.5466-2.4224-1.7276)
So, it is easy to obtain that || V || = 1.4458, κ(V) = 58.7785, || K || = 31.0264 and the poles errors are 1.0e–12*{0.00, 0.0639 ± 0.0888i, –0.1315}.
Case 4: The optimal parameter vectors based on the minimization of J, with a scalar weights as (α = 0.50, β = 0.25, γ = 0.25), are obtained by f1=f2=(-4.1639-11.7234), f3=(13.928413.3837)
Therefore, the following results are obtained ||€V€|| = 1.4009, κ(V) = 57.1757 and || K || = 31.6781. Also, the errors in poles are 1.0e–12*{0.00, –0.1137 ± 0.0586i, 0.1492}.

Now, a perturbation study is undertaken to display the behavior of closed-loop poles in the perturbed system. Consider a small perturbation in the mass Δm = –0.1 kg, so that m – Δm = 9.9 kg, and all the other model parameters are not changed. The closed-loop eigenvalues of the perturbed system and the error norm due to perturbation for the non-robust and robust solutions are illustrated in Table 2. Once more, the closed-loop eigenvalues of the perturbed system for robust solutions are considerably smaller compared with the non-robust solution. If the poles are assigned robustly, then the deviation of closed-loop poles from the assigned values should be small. Figures 10 and 11 describe the state error and state-derivative error trajectories for the non-robust solution and the robust solution of Case 1 with the same initial states x0. The results clearly indicate that the errors for robust solutions are considerably smaller compared with the non-robust one. This demonstrates that the proposed control method is robust against the parameter variation. Figure 10.
The state and state-derivative error trajectories using non-robust solution (singular system). Figure 11.
The state and state-derivative error trajectories using robust solution of Case 1 (singular system). Table 2.
Eigenvalues of perturbed closed-loop system and the error norm
Solution κ(V) Eigenvalues of perturbed closed-loop system Error norm
Non-robust solution 2017.2091 –19.9575±1.4984i, –89.4294, 0.00 60.6334
Robust solutions Case 1 55.8857 –19.9017±9.7177i, –33.6852, 0.00 3.7094
Case 2 240.5875 –17.2638±9.9767i, –41.6888, 0.00 12.3127
Case 3 58.7785 –19.7879±9.7302i, –33.9658, 0.00 3.9954
Case 4 57.1757 –19.8614±9.7413i, –33.7137, 0.00 3.7368

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: This paper presented a complete parametric approach for solving the ESA problem for multivariable linear systems using state-derivative feedback. The main result of the present work is a new and efficient computational algorithm for solving the robust EVA problem via state-derivative feedback. Furthermore, compact parametric expressions for the feedback controller gain matrices are explicitly characterized by a set of free parameter vectors. The parametric solution describes the available degrees-of-freedom offered by the state-derivative feedback in selecting the associated eigenvectors from an admissible class. These freedoms are exploited to improve the closed-loop robustness against perturbation. The proposed approach has been successfully applied to a vibration absorber system. Comparisons between several performance criteria are also presented. This work opens the applicability of the state-derivative feedback methodology for flexible structures when the accelerometer is the only measurement sensor. This work represents unique treatment for this problem in the literature.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The author is very grateful to the reviewers for their helpful comments and suggestions. The comments were very valuable for the paper’s improvement.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
